titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. My Mother, Mrs: Cranch, and Mrs: Charles Adams came into town this Morning.— Mrs: Adams dined with us— And they all returned this Evening to Quincy— I executed this day the Agreements with Messrs: Osgood and Whitney; and with Messrs: S. Clap. & James White, respecting my house in Court-Street— Met Coll: Boyd and Mr: Stackpole, as they were coming to see me— I was engaged as much of the day, as was left me in my preparatory arrangements— Mr: Loud of Weymouth called on me again respecting his affairs; and a moment after he was gone I received a letter with Instructions respecting it, from the Secretary of State— Mr: Gray was also here— I agreed to go, at the latest by Saturday next; if in the mean time I should receive no Counter-Instructions. Mr: D. Everett— Judge Davis— Mr: Shaw, Mr: Emerson, Dr: Welsh—& his son John and daughter Charlotte, and Mr: William Gray junr: were here in the afternoon and Evening.— I had some conversation with Judge Davis respecting my Lectures, which he has consented to revise in the printing, with Mr: Buckminster, and to write an Introduction.— Genl: Dearborn was here on Saturday, and desired me, if I could, to procure some Siberian Wheat,not kiln-dried—which he said could be obtained only by an order of Government— Judge Davis gave me some specimens of Minerals, with Mr: Godon’s Dissertation.

2. This was the day we had fixed upon for our departure; but the difficulty of getting ready, and the letter which I last received from the Secretary of State have detained me for a few days— We all dined at Mr: Gray’s, and Mr: Boylston also dined with us there— After dinner I went to the Miniature Painter Williams’s, for my wife’s pictures, and had two profile shades taken of myself— Return’d to Mr: Gray’s and came home with the Ladies. Then attended club at Dr: Kirkland’s— Almost all the Members were there. The multitude of objects which call for attention at this time, engrosses every moment so much that I have scarcely any left for writing.

3. The payment of bills, the arrangements for disposing of books and furniture; the numbers of people who at every hour of the day are calling, on visits of civility or of business, continue to occupy me almost to distraction— After packing up as I thought all my books, I have two boxes more to pack. Mr: Loud also called upon me again— This afternoon I went out upon the neck, to Mr: J. D. Williams’s, for wine, which I bespoke. Evening at Mr: Emerson’s, and delivered to him the books and papers of the American Academy— Mrs: Adams, and Catherine went out this afternoon with Mr: Ripley and Mr: W. S. Smith to Quincy, to take leave of my Parents and children— I could not go.— I was employed part of this morning, in endeavouring to procure at the Banks some gold, for the expences of my voyage, but did not entirely succeed.

4. Having fixed upon to-morrow for the day of our departure, the pressure of preparation increases upon us as the day approaches: and this day engrossed every moment of our time— I was obliged again to attend at the Banks— Dined with Mr: Joseph Hall— The rest of the family dined at Mr: W. Foster’s— Mr: Loud, Mr: W. Smith, Mr: J. Gallison, and many others called here— We sent to the ship the greatest part of our baggage— I wrote to the Secretary of State, and to Mr: Daschkoff—
